topics.title: Hub
topics.content: hub is layer 1 device that connects one or two computers. A hub is usually termed as a ‚Äòdumb‚Äô device because when a hub receives data, it simply sends data to every other connected device, regardless of the intended recipient; in other word it broadcasts the data across all the connected devices.

topics.title: Switch
topics.content: switch is a layer 2 device that connects one or two computers. A switch send the data to the intended device based on mac address (it unicast the data)

topics.title: Router
topics.content:
Router is a layer 3 device that connects different networks. A router can calculate the best route for sending data from one point to another using an IP address.
 

Routing protocols: Routing protocols are sets of rules and procedures that routers use to communicate with each other to find and select the best paths for forwarding data packets across networks.

Routing Protocols & Easy Two-Sentence Descriptions
RIP (Routing Information Protocol)
RIP uses hop count to find the best path ‚Äî like choosing roads based only on ‚Äúfewest turns.‚Äù
It‚Äôs simple but old, and routers using RIP don‚Äôt know how fast or congested a link is.

OSPF (Open Shortest Path First)
OSPF builds a full map of the network using link-state information ‚Äî like having Google Maps with traffic data.
It picks the best path based on cost (speed, bandwidth), making it fast and intelligent.

EIGRP (Enhanced Interior Gateway Routing Protocol)
EIGRP is Cisco‚Äôs smart hybrid protocol that picks routes using several metrics (delay, bandwidth, reliability).
It converges quickly, like a GPS that instantly recalculates if a road closes.

BGP (Border Gateway Protocol)
BGP runs the internet by letting ISPs exchange routes ‚Äî like countries negotiating which roads connect their borders.
It chooses paths based on policies, not speed, making it extremely powerful but complex.

IS-IS (Intermediate System to Intermediate System)
IS-IS works similar to OSPF, using link-state logic, but is more scalable in very large networks.
Big telecom networks use it because it handles huge topologies with ease.

Static Routing (manual routes)
Static routes are manually added by the admin ‚Äî like telling a router ‚Äúalways use this exact road.‚Äù
They‚Äôre simple and predictable but don‚Äôt adapt automatically if a link fails.

topics.title: MAC address
topics.content: A MAC (Media Access Control address) address is a unique, permanent identifier assigned to a network interface card (NIC) by its manufacturer, used to identify a device on a local network.

topics.title: IP address
topics.content:
IP address: (internet protocol address): its a unique number assigned to every device connected to the internet.
In the world of the internet everything will be remembered or identified by the ip address.
There are two types of IP addresses.
Private IP: which are non-routable in nature. (LAN)
Public IP: which are routable from the internet. (WAN)

ISP: internet service provider

The IP that can not be tracked from the internet is known as non routable or private IP

The IP that can be tracked from the internet is known as routable or public IP
 

Private IP address Range

topics.title: Difference between Private IP and Public IP
topics.content:
Public IP Address
A public IP is your home‚Äôs main address on the Internet, used by the outside world to reach your network.
It is unique globally, assigned by your ISP, and can be accessed over the internet.

Like your house address ‚Äî anyone can send you a letter.


 

Private IP Address
A private IP is the internal address inside your local network, used for devices to communicate with your router.
It is not reachable from the internet directly and must go through NAT to reach outside.

üëâ Real-world example:
Like room numbers inside your house ‚Äî only useful inside, not visible to the outside world.

topics.title: Address Translators
topics.content:
it is the process of converting one IP address to another. Usually translation happens from private to public IP address.

NAT & PAT
NAT: Network address translation. it is a Private IP address or local address that is translated into the public IP address.
PAT: Port Address translation. Private IP addresses are translated into the public IP address through port numbers.

topics.title: Ports list
Threeway hand shake
topics.content:
• It is a method used in the TCP/IP network to create the connection between two hosts.
  • It's a three step process that requires both client and server to exchange the SYN and ACK packages before actual data communication begins.

  •  

Process of three way hand shake

  • The process starts from the client sending the SYN packet to the server which it wants to communicate with, the objective of the packet is to check if the server is open for new connection.
  • If the server is open for the new connection the server will respond with SYN/ACK pocket.
  • Then the client responds with the acknowledgement ACK which establishes the connections between client and server.
  • Upon completion of this process the actual data communication starts between the client and server.

topics.title: Four way hand shake
topics.content:
Four way hand shake is for terminating the connection.

 

1. Host A ‚Üí Host B: FIN flag set.
